No... But you really won't need a gaming keyboard if you can use the keypad primarily. Razer made it to help you keep your hand on the keypad during game play and not worry about hitting the wrong buttons.

No, it does not. I use mine for World of Warcraft and there is a good amount of normal typing involved communicating with other players. The real advantage is that on the Orbweaver, your hand is constantly supported and you are only moving your fingers. On any conventional keyboard you are hover your hands above the keys as you have to reach a lot more keys to type. That hovering makes for fatigue that does not exist in the keypad. Also, because your hand is stationary on the keypad, your key presses are far more accurate in the heat of battle than doing it on a keyboard.

The input is the standard 3.5mm input (the size used for most phones, ipods, etc.). The only way to connect this to a PS3 and have it work is to buy a couple extra things. They are not too expensive, so if you still wish to do so, you can. 1) Buy a USB External Sound Card ( Virtual 5.1-surround USB 2.0 External Sound Card ) -- now the only other problem is: it is one 3.5mm, so it has 3 rings, 1 for each speaker (2) and 1 for a microphone. So you will need to buy a 2) A 3.5mm to headset adapter so that you can plug both in the above item (plugged into the PS3 USB ports.) ( Consumer Electronic Products Smartphone Headset to PC Adapter - Use a 3.5mm iPhone/Smartphone Headset With Your PC, Converts 3.5mm Plug to Dual Mic/Audio 3.5mm, for Skype/VOIP (01-PH35-PC35) Supply Store ) Using this, you can change the original 3.5mm to 2 3.5mm (headphone and microphone) and then plug into usb hookup, then connect the usb to the PS3, which will work.

question_text: My grandsons told me that I sent them the wrong giants. They want the ones that are physically larger. How can I tell by the package.

answers.answer_text: Where the phrase Skylanders giants is on the package. For the "Giant" characters the name "Skylanders Giants" is towards the bottom of the package on the plastic.While on the smaller packages it's on the cardboard backing above the figure.

Giants is a game name, the physical characters in a package come in two sizes. The larger of the two characters that are from the game are obviously wt your grandsons wanted. They are the giant giants if you like. Hope that helps explain the difference. There are many larger giant characters . Ask you grandson what ones are on his wish list, that will still give you the element of surprise per choice.

Your best bet is to ask tour grandsons for the specific names of the Giants they want.  There is one leader Giant for each for each element but on the package you can only find these large leaders by name. Bouncer, Tree Rex, Eye Brawl,Thumpback, Hot Head, Ninjini, Crusher and Swarm are the leader giant names. Ask them which ones of these they don't have. Hope I helped!

There are 8 different Giants for Skylanders Giants: Bouncer, Crusher, Eye Brawl, Hot Head, Ninjini, Swarm, Thump back,  and Tree Rex.  These are the leader giant names and the characters are twice the size at least of the other Skylanders. You can as your grandson which one he is looking for, and you can find most at Toys-R-Us, Wal-Mart, and Target, Best Buy has a small selection. Hope this helps.

question_text: What's the difference between the GT 5 and this GT 5 XL? Why not buy the GT6? ( I would like to purchase for my husband, the one who plays)

answers.answer_text: GT5 XL adds a few special downloadable cars/tracks etc.  GT5 is the full game, but the XL version includes content that came out after the initial release of GT5.  If you bought GT5 and wanted the extra cars, you'd have to pay to download them.  GT6 has a different interface, but many reviews said that GT5 was the purer game.  Read some reviews on GT6 and GT5 to see what you think.

The only cause to buy GT5XL to me are two reasons: to have the complete GT5 lineage which I would do, and to play with the Course Maker which is very nice.  Also, GT5 has B-Spec racing, where you advise a bot driver on how to race, and hope that he improves - not always the case.  Otherwise, GT6 is a much better game.  You don't have the annoying experience point system to unlock cars, tracks and events, you don't have to win or buy a car to get ONE paint chip to paint another... several other things have been done away with in GT6. Get GT5XL for the DLC and updates, but then get GT6 for a better Gran Turismo experience.

question_text: Has anybody tried this with an emulator on Android?

answers.answer_text: I've used 3 of them on various raspberry pi projects with 100% success. I would guess that if your android device has USB Host, you should be fine.

Long story short for future answer-seekers of this question. This controller is a simple HID device. This means it will work on ANY OS to date with USB support. Raspberry Pi is a linux-device and so is Android as it uses the Linux Kernel (although the two differ so much I hate to even call Android Linux.) It'll work in OS X, FreeBSD, Linux, Windows 98 and above, etc.
I am currently using it on a Matricom G-Box Midnight edition, which looks like a Apple tv box and runs a Android Jelly Bean O/S.

Yes it works great hooked up to a usb otg cable on both my galaxy s3 and my rca walmart black friday tablet both running android 4.2+. With the gamepad, cheap tablet, and stand, it makes for a great snes/nes/gb portable emulation system. Fantastic Controller. Needs no drivers for any OS i've tried so far.

I'm using this with RetroPIE on my Raspberry Pi.  Everything works great other than really bad design on the configuration settings in RetroArch (they assume you're using a 360 gamepad.  I have no idea what the basis of such a dumb assumption is, but there you have it.  It takes a bit of figuring out on the initial setup since you have to mentally remap buttons essentially.)
Yes, works fine with Dell Venue 8 (Android) and SNES9x through and OTG adapter. Sometimes it gets disconnected but unplug/replug works, maybe it's because of the adapter.
No but i have used it on a pc emulator works well

question_text: Does it run on PAL or NTSC CDs, will it run in Middle east games Egypt? For powersupply I will get myself a new one or converter

answers.answer_text: NTSC

Assalaamu Alaikum. I brought an Xbox 360 from America to Saudi Arabia. I was so grateful that I researched online about power supply to hear people had blown their whole system when they used 220v . I went ahead and had some electricians come and set up a 110v outlet so that I wouldn't need a converter but I don't know if they do that in Egypt. The game console is PAL so NTSC CD's wouldn't work unless they are specifically labeled as "region free" which you can check before buying a CD, of course making sure your TV s also compatible (newer TV's have both). We buy Xbox games from Saudi, all PAL and compatible as well.

question_text: Why is it mature?

answers.answer_text:
It has mild blood, violence, very little language. It just BARELY scrapes up to mature. I have had this talk with a bunch of people wanting to get their child Reach. It should not be rated Mature, and the thousands and thousands of times I have played it I have never felt "disturbed" or like it was inappropriate for children. You DO do things like run aliens over, or jab a knife in their brainpan, but it is just comic violence. Like LEGO games; isn't it morbid to hit someone and have them explode into pieces? ;) Just saying, this game has violence but it is very mild. Many of the Halo games are not deserving of their Mature rating. Hope this helps you some!

question_text: where are the games stored

answers.answer_text: The unit is used in conjunction with your smart phone, in my case a Galaxy 3. The games are stored in the phone memory
I'll need to ask my son but I'm assuming in the devices memory

The games, regardless of whether they're the paid-for MOGA games that you can buy through the app, or the ones that you've downloaded from the Google Play, Amazon app, or any other store, are all downloaded and installed to your phone's memory, or your micro SD card, depending on your phone's software and file storage options.
In my galaxy s3
Games are stored on your phone.  The controller has no flash memory.
they are always on your tablet or smartphone, the controller is merely a means by which to control the physical movements involved with the game characters

the games are stored on your phones main memory but you can also contact the game provider or developer to get the apk so you can store it on your sd card so you wont have to take up space on your main memory, note when you get the the from the moga pivot app this gives you the option were to get it from via the play store or via the games web site, but it would be better to go to the games web site email them have them send you apk file of the game so you can store it on the sd card, also note when you do download the game from the playstore this will be downloaded to your main memory taking up space from your phones memory, also note if you want to port it to your sd card just go to settings and the applications then under downloads find the game then move to sd card but because the game has to run when being used from the main memory only a part of the download will be set to your sd card so better to get the apk if you can.

question_text: HD Possible?  Or at least widescreen?  or does it lock you into 480i?

answers.answer_text: It is not capable of any form of HD as it only ouputs 480i via a RCA cable.

The Wii Mini is capable of widescreen (16:9) or standard (4:3), but ONLY in 480i with the supplied composite cable.  480p, which is possible on a regular Wii, isn't supported on the Mini.  Even component cables from other Wiis will not work on the Mini, meaning you are stuck with 480i and the composite cable only.
Yes it is possible but just with component cables, wii is not hdmi compatible

question_text: How's the wireless range on this thing compare to the gold version?

answers.answer_text:
To be honest, I haven't used the gold headset and i havent been able to test the unobstructed range seeing as how I live in a small house. I do know for a fact that the gold has a better range and battery life seeing as how it's newer. BUUUT in MY opinion, the pulse elites are better because you can make anything with an aux out port wireless. They feel amazing. I had them charging and did a 24 hour game session and i had absolutely no discomfort (as far as the headset goes that is. They will reach through your average wall. I was listening to music from my ps3 in my bathroom that is about 15-20 feet away with to walls. Now I can't say for sure if you will get that kind of reach through the walls at your house or not but that isn't a really big deal. All around I would pick these over the gold anytime. Now don't get me wrong, they're both AMAZING headsets!!
